item.title: nonplanarity and javascript
item.author: me@daniel-salmon.com (daniel salmon)
item.description: this spring i came across introduction to graph theory by richard j. trudeau, a wonderful little book on the basics of graph theory. honestly, if i were to suggest a few books to younger me, this would definitely be on that list. the prerequisites are none, yet trudeau is able to build up quite a bit of the beautiful structure of graphs, touching on planarity, euler’s formula, colorings and more. admittedly, this wouldn’t serve as a sole reference on the subject, but it does serve its intended purpose as an introduction.

item.title: papers
item.author: me@daniel-salmon.com (daniel salmon)
item.description: in reverse chronological order: Seong Youl Choi, Neil D. Christensen, Daniel Salmon, and Xing Wang. 2015. Spin and chirality effects in antler-topology processes at high energy e+e-colliders. Eur. Phys. J. C 75, 10 (2015), 481. https://doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-015-3682-4 arXiv: https://arxiv.org/abs/1503.02666 Neil D. Christensen and Daniel Salmon. 2014. New method for the spin determination of dark matter. Phys. Rev. D 90, 1 (2014), 014025. https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevD.90.014025 arXiv: https://arxiv.org/abs/1311.6465

item.title: interests
item.author: me@daniel-salmon.com (daniel salmon)
item.description: someday i’ll fill this out more thoroughly, but shooting from the hip some of the topics i’m most interested in / working on these days: distributed systems cryptography the relation of the above two with game theory databases side interests: coffee quantum mechanics / quantum field theory transcendental numbers hacking on whatever is holding my attention that day brazilian jiu-jitsu although with the pandemic i’ve just been riding my bike things i’m pretty sure i’m not interested in:

item.title: about
item.author: me@daniel-salmon.com (daniel salmon)
item.description: i’m daniel, a phd student in electrical and computer engineering at the university of pittsburgh. that sounds a bit more hands on than my work actually is, and my research interests are pretty broad, although computation—broadly defined—is kind of the central theme. check out interests for more. i’ve been fortunate enough to work with some pretty talented people, and a quick summary of where i’ve been in the past: wilmerlab – currently niche.
